reference.title: Overview of Dynamic Table of Context
reference.shortdesc: The Dynamic Table of Context (DToC) lets users reveal information about their text that is not necessarily discovered when reading, such as word frequencies. DToC also allows users to customize their document with annotations and adding tags.

section.title: DToC overview
section.p: The homepage of DToC lets users enter URLs, text, or XML documents. DToC is optimized for XML documents. Users upload pre existing XML documents by selecting the gear icon in the top right corner and then following the steps described in the “Upload your XML document to DToC” (linked below).
Additionally, users can paste/type in a URL or non-XML text into the text box provided on the first page of DToC.
Once you have enter the text, the “Reveal” button moves you into the main page of DToC.
The Dynamic Tables of Contexts is divided into four columns.

The text area contains the text of the document you’ve uploaded or entered into DToC. If your document has multiple sections then only the first section is visible in the text area when DToC loads. Below the text, at the bottom of the column, is a “Next Chapter” button (and/or a “Previous Chapter depending on what section you are viewing) that allows users to navigate between different sections of a document or different components of a collection.

The document model contains multiple lines that represent paragraphs of your document and are divided into sections or chapters by white spaces. These lines can become highlighted if they contain an index term, tag, or stat from the left column. Additionally, you can click on one of the lines to move the text area to that section of the text.

The table of contents displays the multiple sections or chapters of your document in a list. You can move between sections or chapters by clicking on the different titles located in the Table of Contents. This will reload the text in the right column to the section or chapter you’ve selected.
The left column provides you with four options to explore your text.

ul.li: The “Index” column arranges the terms alphabetically and displays the frequency of different terms in your document. Your index has to follow a certain XML syntax, one may want to upload a document that already has an index or to add an index to your document, please read “Adding an index to your XML document” linked below.
The “Tags” column shows all the XML tags searchable in your document. By clicking on the tags in the list you can see where they are situated in the sections.

The “Stats” tab displays the word frequencies in your document. You can sort the stats list by heading, list order, and category. Additionally, if you want to view just a few of the terms you can create a favorite list.
The “Annotations” displays any annotations made in the text area. To use this function you must be logged in to the “AnnotateIt” tool (a popup prompt comes up when you open this tab).

section.p: The Table of Contents, “Index,” and “Tag” tabs are only available if you upload an XML document with a structure compatible with DToC. See “Upload your XML document to DToC” (linked below) for more information and one of the XML document templates to get started.

link.desc: The Table of Contents shows the section or chapter breakdown of your document. The ToC will expand to display the information selected from the left column.

link.linktext: Left column of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: This column allow users to search and browse the document by key terms, tags, and word frequency information.
Please feel free to download the DToC XML template or ignore it, depending on your XML expertise and/or adventurous spirit.
DToC provides different features to share and save your document for future use.

link.linktext: Uploading your XML document to DToC
link.desc: DToC requires XPath information to upload original XML documents. These may changes depending on how you have structured your document. The below information is for a XML document that follows the template structure, but we have noted how you can change the XPath information to match your document.

link.linktext: Uploading text and URLs into DToC
link.desc: Some features will be unavailable using this method (like the index).

link.linktext: Navigating text in the table of contents
link.desc: The Table of Contents displays terms selected (from the left column) and lets users move through the text by clicking on them. This allows for in-depth exploration of terms without scrolling through large chunks of text.
The Document Model is a deconstructed version of your document. Each section of grey lines represents a different section/chapter/article within the document.

The text is separated into chapters, sections, or articles by the XML document. The text area loads individual sections, so the whole document will not appear unless there are no text divisions in the document.

link.linktext: Filtering index terms, tags, and stats
link.desc: The search feature narrows down terms automatically as you type, whether they have the specific combination of letters you are typing anywhere in the word (not just if the word starts with the letters you are typing).

The search box is autocomplete-enabled. If you don't use that function (e.g. you continue to type your word or phrase without selecting a term from the drop down list) your search may not work if it has a spelling error or extra space.

When you move between different tabs in the left column they will not be filtered by the Chapter you have selected in the previous column. However, when you return to the initial tab, the chapter filter will remain selected.
You can customize how you view word frequencies in DToC by different organizational headings and by how the words are displayed under those headings.

link.linktext: Viewing stats by chapters and collections

link.desc: You can add as many terms as you would like to your “Favorites” list, either all at once or a few at a time.
You can add context to your annotations using the "AnnotateIt" tool. For more information about signing up to “AnnotateIt” see “Login/Annotator Authentication.”
The left column has a list of the tags found in the document. You can add new tags to the list, those that are found in your XML document or not.
